events.event_description: The Francis Scott Key Bridge collapsed into the Patapsco River, causing a complete halt to all shipping traffic at the Port of Baltimore.
events.citation: The collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge into the Patapsco River on March 26 has temporarily halted all shipping traffic from the Port of Baltimore.

events.event_description: Coal exports from Baltimore surged to 28 million short tons in 2023, driven by increased demand from Asia.
events.citation: Exports from Baltimore surged to 28 million short tons in 2023, mainly because of growing demand for U.S. coal in Asia.

events.event_description: Steam coal exports from Baltimore increased significantly from a 12 million short ton average to 19 million short tons.
events.citation: Those shipments averaged around 12 million short tons from 2019 to 2022 before surging to 19 million short tons in 2023.

events.event_description: Japan became the top recipient of metallurgical coal from Baltimore, receiving 28% of metallurgical coal exports.
events.citation: The top recipient in 2023 was Japan, which received 28% of the metallurgical coal shipped through the port of Baltimore.

events.event_description: Baltimore recorded minimal petroleum product movements with only one gasoline import and three petroleum-related export cargos.
events.citation: According to ship tracking data, there was one shipment of gasoline into the Port of Baltimore in 2023, and there were three petroleum-related export cargos in all of 2023.
